Luis Suarez believes Philippe Coutinho would bring “a lot” to Barcelona – but praised his former Liverpool team-mate for his “professional” response to having his move to Camp Nou denied this summer.

Suarez on Coutinho: “Obviously he must have ambition because he’s a player who has ambition and any player would want to come to Barca. He went through a difficult moment but as a professional he continued to show how good a player he is and the personal quality he has.”

Sadio Mané has joined the Senegal squad accompanied by a club physio to ensure he suffers no setback in his recovery from a hamstring problem. (Chris Bascombe)

Mané made a successful return to Premier League duty last weekend, but there is understandable concern he is eased back to full match fitness during the international break. (Chris Bascombe)

Klopp: “I really believe in second chances. I had more than two, so I like to give players a chance or two. It starts with a dream. It’s not important to be the best, but it’s important to beat the best.”

Klopp: “My managerial style? I hope no one falls asleep when I answer. The most important skill in life is common sense. I’m not skilled in intelligence, but common sense I take to the highest level.”

Klopp: “I love to play entertaining football. I rather have someone hit the cross bar than not shoot. I don’t like a victory with 80%. You’re not completely exhausted and it’s a waste of time. I’m not the smartest manager in the world, but maybe the most passionate.”

Klopp: “Motivation should never be a problem. The best thing you can learn in football is hard work will pay off. Who am I to tell you what your limit is? In life it’s not about where you go. I never dreamed to be the @LFC manager as it didn’t make sense. It’s about hard work.”

Klopp: “I will never tell a player he is never good enough. If he is in my team and he’s good enough, it’s then my fault. The defeats are my responsibility and the victories the players’. The best education in football is the game itself.”

Klopp: “How do I handle conflict? I’m the boss. As the boss, I have fantastic staff but the final decision is always mine. I don’t expect perfection. I can’t talk to a player about everything. But you have to let the football do the talking. In life you have to work hard.”

Klopp: “Rift with the managers? The dugout on the field is like Las Vegas! What is said in the dugout stays in the dugout. I don’t concentrate on what the other managers are doing. We aren’t divas. You can’t win the game in the dugout.”

Klopp: “I’m Christian. How can you have more luck in your life than you can imagine & everything worked out. My life is much better than I expected. How can I be a horrible person? Staying down to earth is a question of intelligence. As long as my family is rested I’m happy.”
Klopp expects Adam Lallana to be available for selection for the game with former club Southampton on November 18th. (Paul Joyce)

Keita on Mané at Salzburg: “At first, I wasn’t starting and it was very frustrating. I didn’t like it and it made the settling-in period harder. But Sadio said: ‘My little brother, stay calm. Your chance will come and when it does, you will make the most of it.’”

Keita on Mané: “Salzburg improved me & I learnt so much there, I got a really tactical education. Sadio was important for me, he still is! To me, he’s my big brother. He likes to learn new things, to improve and to push himself and we are the same. He’s a good example for me.”

Keita on Mané: “I asked him about Liverpool and he told me this is an amazing club with talented players, a great manager and lots of ambition. The city and the people are really nice and he will feel at home here.”

Keita: “All my friends were Liverpool supporters, though, and I really liked the club too so we decided on them. I don’t think any of them or I could really imagine that I would grow up to actually wear a real Liverpool shirt and represent the real Liverpool!”

Keita: “My father is a huge fan! As far back as I can remember, he has been talking about them. Before I even knew what Liverpool was as a kid, he was mad about them. Of course, when he found out about their interest and when the deal for next season was done, he was delighted.”

Moreno on last season: "Already in summer I saw that the season was going to be f***** up and that's how it was. I cannot find a reason for what happened."

Moreno on talking to Klopp about issues last season: "He told me the team was fine… that I should continue working. I did, but the opportunity didn't come. I went to talk to him five or six times and the message was the same… but nothing changed."

Moreno: “When I saw that a right-footed midfielder like Milner was the left-back, I thought something was happening. He [Klopp] didn't give me explanations.”

Moreno on talking to Klopp about issues last season: "He told me the team was fine… that I should continue working. I did, but the opportunity didn't come. I went to talk to him five or six times and the message was the same… but nothing changed."

Moreno: “When I saw that a right-footed midfielder like Milner was the left-back, I thought something was happening. He [Klopp] didn't give me explanations.”

england qualified for a world cup because henderson didnt show up ğŸ’ª

Jurgen Klopp believes Alberto Moreno can serve as the perfect example for Andy Robertson as the Liverpool new boy looks to make his mark at Anfield.

Asked whether Moreno had 'won the fans back', Klopp said:”lYes, because the players can always do that. If they have the quality they can win the fans back because we have no real idea about the games four or five weeks away or in the past. We are easy to convince in the moment.”

Klopp on Moreno: “He did it now consistently which is really nice. I am happy for him because he had a very difficult situation last year. That’s how it was. We spoke before the last season what we wanted him to do differently. He needed a bit of time and now he is doing well.”

Klopp: “Hopefully he can do well in the future again because that’s how you show consistency. He has done that so far but that is the challenge for him and the guys in the future.”

Klopp: “It’s the exact same situation for Andy Robertson. People will say ‘why do you do that? Because he is here and not playing? Because he has to learn. But there is no problem. We are in conversation, talk about it and he has to improve.”

Klopp on Robertson: “As long as the other players are doing like this. Alberto is like a little machine, he never shows when he is tired and stuff like this. Andrew has had a little less rhythm. So you think now, okay, he will have a game with the national team and come back.“

Klopp: ”We will have a little internal game then and that’s good for Andy. So he’s on a good way, a really good way. It’s going well apart from maybe he is not happy he cannot start so often as he would have thought from the beginning.”

Klopp: “But it’s all about improvement and then to be ready for the moment you are used.”

Andy Massey, Head of medical services, on Klopp: "Jurgen’s philosophy is very much that we’ve got to run further, run faster, run quicker than every other team because if we can do that then the skill will take over."

Massey: "So we’ve got to put the players in a position where they can do that. When Jurgen first came into the club, we tried to put that in there but the boys weren’t up to that physical level yet to meet the demands."

Massey: "At one stage, we had 13 hamstring injuries but now, with the benefit of two pre-seasons, we’re seeing the boys work so much harder and they look like they’re more protected."

Andy Massey, Head of medical services: "So far this year, touch wood, we’ve had very few soft-tissue injuries and that’s coming from the fact the players are more accustomed to doing the massive workloads because they’ve had two full pre-seasons under their belts."
